Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Boron Carbide Nanowires - Structure and Transport Property Relations
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Thermoelectrics, a direct energy conversion technology between thermal and electrical energy, could generate significant impact on many energy-related issues the world is facing. Over the past decade, significant progress has been made in creating better nanostructured materials to improve the efficiency of thermoelectric energy conversion. However, to date, most efforts have been focused on low temperature thermoelectric materials for refrigeration applications. High temperature nanostructured thermoelectric materials, which could harvest electricity from waste heat, have not received as much attention. Boron carbides, a class of complex ceramic materials, have been projected as promising candidates for thermoelectric applications. Boron carbide nanowires, with desirable confinement effects to the transport of charge and energy carriers, could have even better thermoelectric performance than bulk boron carbides. In this project, the fundamental structure-property relations for boron carbide nanowires of different diameters, crystalline structures, and compositions are being constructed, which is critical for manufacturing the best performance boron carbide nanowires for high performance thermoelectric energy conversion. The project has integrated research and education components to train graduate students in an interdisciplinary environment, and to extend the impact to underrepresented minorities and K-12 students through demonstration of the importance of nanomaterials in energy technology.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project aims at constructing the structure-transport property relations of boron carbide nanowires, a class of complex ceramic nanowires that is promising for high temperature thermoelectric power generation. The approach is to integrate rational materials synthesis, transport property measurements at individual nanostructure level, thorough structure characterization of measured samples, and theoretical analysis to achieve in-depth understanding of charge and energy transport. The structure-property relation is critical to design and fabricate boron carbide nanowires with the best thermoelectric properties, which could generate significant impact on industrial waste heat recovery. The project tackles an area where little research has focused to date, namely, nanostructured high temperature thermoelectrics, that has the potential to make use of waste heat. Successful implementation of the project can lead to an in-depth understanding of transport properties of boron carbide nanowires, and create a class of high performance thermoelectric nanomaterials. The project trains students in an interdisciplinary environment, which prepare them well for today's cutting-edge multidisciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The main objective of this collaborative project between UNC Charlotte and Vanderbilt University is to study the structure and transport property relation of boron carbide nanowires. Our systematic work demonstrates novel and intriguing effects of kinks on thermal transport. More specifically, it was found that (1) single crystalline and defect-free kinks in boron carbide nanowires can pose a resistance that is 30 times higher than that of a corresponding straight nanowire of equivalent length; and (2) structural defects such as stacking faults and dislocations in the crystalline kinks can assist phonon transmission through the kink and reduce the kink resistance, instead of posing resistance. These unexpected observations can be explained by disclosing that phonon transport in boron carbides are highly anisotropic; and the combined effects of back reflection of highly focused phonons and the compulsory mode conversion across the kink lead to the pronounced kink resistance. The significantly reduced thermal conductivity of kinked nanowires points out a new route to effectively enhance the thermoelectric performance of nanomaterials given that many important thermoelectric materials such as Bi2Te3 and SnSe are highly anisotropic with large phonon focusing effects and can take advantage of the same mechanism to reduce the thermal conductivity.

During our study of boron carbide nanowires, we noticed several previously ignored factors such as thickness of amorphous layers, shape/dimension of cross-sectional areas could affect the measured transport properties. To understand the effect of amorphous oxide layers (which is commonly observed on the surface of nanostructures), we performed transport study on double silicon nanoribbons with a layer of amorphous-SiO2 sandwiched in between. The thickness of the oxide layer was varied between 1.7 nm and 5.1 nm, by using different surface treatment methods.  Our results showed ∼11% thermal conductivity enhancement at 300 K for a sample with a ~5 nm oxide layer, indicating the thermal phonons can ballistically transmit through the thin amorphous layer interfaces. This ballistic phonon penetration depth is nearly one order of magnitude higher than the predication of Einstein?s random walk model commonly accepted in the research field. This work provides important insight into thermal management of electronic devices.

 

Broader Impacts

The results obtained from this project were (1) disseminated though six journal publications, and thirteen conference presentations and invited talks; (2) discussed with undergraduate and graduate students who took courses in the field of materials science and nanotechnology at UNC Charlotte; and (3) displayed at the STEM fair organized by the National Council of Negro Women.

The project provided unique training opportunities to four graduate students, including two female ones, from the Department of Mechanical Engineering and the Nanoscales Science program at UNC Charlotte.  Among the four students, three had graduated with their Ph.D. degrees. They are now either working at Intel as senior engineers or at an oversea university as a senior lecturer.

The project also offered Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) opportunity to five undergraduates with diverse academic background in the fields of Physics, Chemistry and Mechanical Engineering from the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, Davison College and UNC Charlotte. Four REU participants are now working in industry companies, and one is a graduate student.
